message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Herpes simplex virus is sensitive to ethanol and can be effectively prevented by disinfecting with 70% ethanol. Hepatitis A virus is resistant to ethanol and handwashing with soap and water is recommended instead. Parvovirus and polyomavirus are also resistant to ethanol.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Herpes simplex virus is enveloped and can be easily killed by 70% ethanol. Hepatitis A virus is a non-enveloped virus and is relatively resistant to ethanol. Parvovirus and Polyomavirus are also non-enveloped and are resistant to most disinfectants.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, Herpes simplex virus is the most susceptible to disinfection by ethanol. Hepatitis A virus, parvovirus, and polyomavirus are not as effectively killed by ethanol.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Herpes simplex virus is susceptible to inactivation by alcohol. Ethanol disrupts the lipid membrane of the virus and renders it noninfectious.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Ethanol is a common disinfectant and can kill many types of viruses, but Herpes simplex virus is enveloped and more susceptible to ethanol than non-enveloped viruses such as Hepatitis A virus, Parvovirus, and Polyomavirus. Therefore, the use of ethanol is most likely to be effective in preventing the transmission of Herpes simplex virus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Herpes simplex virus is susceptible to ethanol disinfection. Ethanol has limited activity against non-enveloped viruses like Hepatitis A and Parvovirus, and Polyomavirus can survive on surfaces for an extended period of time, making it resistant to disinfection measures.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Ethanol is an effective disinfectant against enveloped viruses such as Herpes simplex virus, but not against non-enveloped viruses such as Hepatitis A virus, Parvovirus, or Polyomavirus. Therefore, option (D) is the correct answer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Ethanol is effective in destroying enveloped viruses, which include Herpes simplex virus. Hepatitis A virus, Parvovirus, and Polyomavirus are non-enveloped viruses and are not as susceptible to ethanol disinfection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Disinfecting with 70% ethanol is effective in preventing transmission of enveloped viruses, such as herpes simplex virus. Hepatitis A virus is not enveloped, and parvovirus and polyomavirus are resistant to ethanol disinfection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Herpes simplex virus (HSV) is enveloped, meaning it has a fragile lipid envelope that can be easily disrupted by disinfectants like ethanol. Disinfecting the laboratory benches with 70% ethanol can effectively prevent transmission of HSV.
